story.text: A __Thoughtful Dialogue__ is a rare thing. There is a great deal of writing, and comment. There is chat. But much if not all of this is a barely disguised battle of egos, so much so that many economists and theoreticians of democracy view this as a fundamental natural law - the [[Law of Competition]].
# Structure?

Instead we should explore the rules of dialogue. Rules you might ask? Well dialogue has structure, it is not a monologue, it is not simply shouting at each other. There is form to this madness. And their are many forms of dialogue.
One general rule that has been encouraged is to listen first. Better still would be the algorithm proposed in my historical context by [[Karl Popper]]:

1. [[Listen]] to the argument
1. Put the argument [[In Your Own Words]]
1. [[No Straw Men]]. Strengthen it, wherever you can
1. [[Address the argument]]
1. [[Propose a better idea]] (if you can)
1. Explain clearly why it is a better idea ([[Argue]])
Only the latter half of this process (stages 4-6) would be considered an argument. The first half would be a political suicide in most debates. But the combination - wow.

This is not the only structure, it may not even be to your liking, there are doubtless many many better algorithms out there in the infinite domain of evolutionary knowledge. But the important thing to note is the role of structure.

Professional settings, like a court room with a jury, or a science lab, have their own rules and structures. Ossified maybe, and [[This is a problem]], but invaluable in giving us the space of time for many minds to combine productively.
# Flow?

A [[Thoughtful Dialogue]] should also flow. We can imagine it rhythmically moving back and forth between the participants. A good conversation may well have certain musical qualities, there should be a pace to it, and perhaps some drama, or narrative structure.

Certainly we encourage a [[slow crawl]], where we can combine the solitary pursuit of contemplation with focussed and considered responses to specific or fundamental issues raised in the previous verse. By dialogue we do not imply synchronous real-time communication. Both those [[shibboleth]]s can be broken as needed. Minds can dance in many productive ways.
- [[Why we dislike books]]
# Why we love books

We love books for their slow pace. We like the asynchronous nature of flow, and we like the ability to support a structured non-linearity. But most of all we like the pace in which a set of interconnected thoughts can be explored thoughtfully over days and weeks.
# In wiki

Wiki, and to be precise only federated wiki supports slow thoughtful dialogue between authors. We write, we borrow from others, we respond - without pressure or gain. It is a fertile ground on top of which to build [[new forms of conversation]].
# Diversity of structure

Federated wiki encourages diversity. We enable a [[chorus of voices]] and experiments in structure. We look to collect [[conversation principles]] and craft a [[conversation pattern language]]. In different places in [[the federation]] we experiment with software augmented applications of such patterns, and observe their effects.
# Future

We look to explore, our use of media, and of physical meetings, and virtual space. How we reframe academic conferences is one such example. We also look to reframe the way incentives work in academic publishing. Technology allows us to remix and craft a full range of creative and motivational factors into new forms.

In particular we look to add:

- [[Argument Map]]s
- [[Deliberative Science]]

item.text: [[Computational speech act model]]s of [[Humanâ€“computer interaction]] have been developed. [[Speech act]] theory has been used to model [[conversation]]s for automated classification and retrieval - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_act#In_computer_science wikipedia]

item.title: Conversation as Creative Speech
item.text: Wiki is slow, probably too slow. Chat is fast, probably too fast. Can we have it both ways in one place?

item.title: Conversation Piece
item.text: [[Transmediale]] reboots itself with a new performative and participatory format for its 29th edition. Under the name Conversation Piece, the event creates an intensive space of exchanges, murmurs, and transitions, with dialogues initiated before the event and continued afterwards - [http://transmediale.de/ transmediale.de]

item.title: Conversational Space
item.text: Here we describe the architecture of conversation, in a system or design perspective, not as a singular temporal event but as a network process that occurs across time and space.

item.title: Documentary Events
item.text: [[Happenings]] in physical space are more like workshops than they are lectures or passive viewing experiences. We should explore how we can use these events to film more things, and interview and bring more people into the conversation.

item.title: Geographic Conversations
item.text: We are collecting interviews and thought pieces from around the world using mobile phones, and archiving these sound samples together with their [[GPS]] locations.

item.title: Conversations for Action on Service Systems Thinking
item.text: In 2014, the focus for Service Systems Thinking is (i) Conversations for Orientation, and (ii) Conversations for Possibilities.  The first actions are to get the word out out, and canvass for collaborating authors.

item.title: Conversations for Orientation on Service Systems Thinking
item.text: Service systems thinking builds on the foundations of a variety of fields.  An appreciation of parts of those fields can serve as a common understanding to be cross-appropriated for further development of a body of knowledge.

item.title: Conversations for Possibilities on Service Systems Thinking
item.text: With Service Systems Thinking at its inception, community participants can discuss potential futures for their collaborations.

item.title: Conversation Clubs
item.text: We're generating an index of conversations that links to all copies of that conversation. This opens a new tab where the neighborhood will contain only the sites owning and mentioned on those pages.

item.title: Slowcasting
item.text: Just came across this from Walter. Super similar to what I've been working on in terms of [[Conversations Across Space]] and the [[Outlandish Academy]].

item.title: Dynamic Conversation
item.text: Conversation becoming an improvised real-time simulation for exploring models of thought.

item.title: The Garden and the Stream
item.text: A decade and a half ago a set of innovators mapped Usenet and mailing list culture onto the hypertext environment of the web. Many good things resulted, but the cracks in this approach are beginning to show. We propose that an older and alternate approach to conversation, here named The Garden, is required to balance the useful energy of the endless stream of self-assertion we find ourselves in.

item.title: Distributed Unconference
item.text: We need to be able to hold rich distributed conversations. This is both a core part of the process of deliberation in the [[Parliament of Things]], and a bootstrapping process in order to enable us to design the tools and techniques that we need to support the construction of this new democracy. It is a pressing question of practice, not merely theory - [http://www.parliamentofthings.org/thing/distributed-unconferences/ parliamentofthings.org]

item.title: Analysis of Behaviours for Civil Discourse
item.text: Here I propose the outline for investigating how new techniques in [[Conversation Analysis]] could be used to question the efficacy of various formats for [[Civil Discourse]]. Perhaps such an approach could go toward helping the [[Facilitation]] studies community design  better forums for the [[Public Sphere]].

item.title: Decentralised Conversation
item.text: Decentralised [[Conversation]] is a conversation which happens between people or groups of people at different geographical locations but not an online only conversation. It can be done synchronously or asynchronously.

item.title: Conversation Factors
item.text: According to news value theory, journalists select events for news production that contain so-called news factors (Galtung & Ruge, 1965).

item.title: Conversations Across Space
item.text: We understand what a conversation is, how it can be conducted. We value good quality conversations that are respectful, in which each party deepens their learning and understanding. Yet we have little idea how to conduct such conversations across space.

item.title: Political Conversation
item.text: How to turn the political conversation around

item.title: Punching Trees Next to People
item.text: An example of how shared work builds relationships sometimes where conversations might fail. Plus, I just wanted to share it.

item.title: Real Space Conversations
item.text: At Chaos Communication Congress this year we have tried a simple set up and one of the elements of real Spaces Studio: a table projection from a light and affordable pico projector, showing content relevant to the conversation we are having around the table.

item.title: Structured Conversation Platform
item.text: Examples of structured conversation platforms include [[Compendium]], [[Cohere]], [[Debategraph]],  [[TruthMapping]], [[Climate Collaboratorium]], and [[Argument Mapping]] and an emerging list of others.

item.title: Theatre Conversations
item.text: Many theatres host events to go with a production in which the Director and / or cast take place in a conversation about the piece being performed or theatre in general. Here we look at how we might alter or extend this format.
